summary: This is a sealed affirmation and application by an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, filed under the All Writs Act, seeking a court order to unseal discovery materials from a settled civil defamation lawsuit (Giuffre v. Maxwell) held by the law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP. The materials are sought for a then-non-public federal grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking of minors. The document includes the court's protective order from the civil case and the resulting order granting the government's request.

events.title: Civil Defamation Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Plaintiff (Virginia Giuffre) files a civil action against Ghislaine Maxwell in SDNY, alleging Maxwell made defamatory statements denying Giuffre was a victim of sex crimes by Epstein and Maxwell.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: Judge Robert W. Sweet issues a protective order in the civil case (Giuffre v. Maxwell), restricting disclosure of materials marked 'CONFIDENTIAL'.

events.title: Civil Case Settled
events.description: The parties enter into a settlement agreement and voluntarily dismiss the civil defamation lawsuit.

events.title: Government Seeks to Unseal Civil Discovery
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney files a sealed affirmation and application under the All Writs Act, seeking an order to access sealed discovery from the settled civil case for a grand jury investigation into Epstein and others.

events.title: Court Orders Release of Materials
events.description: Judge Robert W. Sweet grants the government's application, ordering Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP to provide the sealed civil discovery materials to the government for the grand jury investigation.

keyFacts: In February 2019, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY was conducting a non-public federal grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and others for sex trafficking of minors (Sections 1591, 1594(c), 2422(b) of Title 18).

The government sought discovery materials from a settled 2015 civil defamation lawsuit (Giuffre v. Maxwell) that were under a protective order, believing they contained information relevant to the criminal investigation.

The law firm Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP, which represented the plaintiff in the civil case, believed the protective order precluded them from complying with a grand jury subpoena without court permission.
The court granted the government's ex parte application, allowing the law firm to provide the confidential civil discovery materials to the grand jury.
The existence and scope of the criminal investigation in the SDNY was not publicly known as of February 2019, and the application was filed under seal to prevent alerting potential targets.
